reviews: I'm surprised that someone hasn't started charging for this! It was so lovely to stand and watch the sea lions playing, swimming, diving and frolicking. An hour went by in a flash!

Walked here from my hotel every morning at low tide to watch the seal mothers and pups sunning themselves and nursing on the sand. Good views from above on the sidewalk, but definitely walk around the horseshoe shaped seawall too, to watch them swimming in the shallows together.

This is a must see if you are visiting the San Diego area. The sea lions or seals (lol) are just so adorable! Because we visited in February during their pupping season, all the little babies were there scooting around right next to their mothers! It was the cutest thing ever!! Definitely take a visit here, and then walk about .3 miles to some nice restaurants and shops.

I love coming to the Children's Pool to see the seals. Since they've remodeled the lifeguard station it's nice that they have bathrooms but beware they are not much better than a porta-potty.

The parking around the area is terrible as well so expect to drive around for a while to find something close or expect to park further away and have a decent walk, maybe up and down hills.

But with all that, it's worth it to come and just hang out on the sea wall and spend time watching the seals sleep or play, especially when all the babies are around.

If you come at low tide, the La Jolla tide pools are a short walk from the Children's Pool and that is always an adventure. If you come at high tide, expect to get a little wet as the waves crash against the sea wall while you're watching the seals.

A great experience!

This beautiful area at the point of the La Jolla coastal drive is so incredibly beautiful whether you are driving, walking, biking.... or sitting on a grassy spot for morning or sunset.

The controversy surrounding the area called the Children’s Pool is based on the sea wall that was built to create a sheltered natural water area in which children could learn to swim. The protection afforded by the sea wall indeed protected against the waves and many, many children learned to swim there.

In the last decade though, seals have overtaken the area and have chosen to do their pupping on the beach. All CA beaches are open to swimmers/people, thus the beach has become a point of interaction between the seals and people. The mire seals, the more poop in the water and the higher fecal organisms contaminating the water. The more people, the more chance of a negative interaction between a sea mammal and human.

And thus the legal battle between beach access (people) and the environmentalists (for the seals). Aggressiveness and bullhorns has sometimes shown the worst side of people.

And thus let me get this review back to where it belongs.... to the natural beauty of our incredible coastline, especially at The Children’s Pool. My children and I have actually seen a pod of whales sauntering by this area of the coast and we just love enjoying our beautiful coast. So I invite you to enjoy our beautiful coast as well.

If you visit the Children’s Pool, be sure to walk out onto the sea wall, it’s great!! Please don’t bother the seals.... it’s not good for anyone. No selfies with them either!!

Parking is tight so just be patient as you look for parking on the side streets. Restrooms are available at the lifeguard station. There are many coffee shops and cafes within an easy walk from The Children’s Pool.

This American Life is one of my favorite Podcasts, and a few weeks ago they replayed an episode about the huge arguments over the seals at Children's Pool in La Jolla, so I had to check it out while I'm down here!
So the "Children's Pool" is this lovely beach and cove created by a sea wall that was built in 1931 so that you can safely neglect your children while they play in the ocean without waves. The seals decided that they loved the spot too, and for decades people and seals happily swam and sunbathed together. A few years ago, a group calling themselves Seal Docents made official looking uniforms and lanyards and started guarding the beach and aggressively stopping the public from sharing the area with the seals. It turned into a huuuge battle in the community and the police were called so often that they eventually stopped responding to calls to come down to the area. Many locals had fond childhood memories from Children's Pool and were incensed that they were being pushed off.
I'm not sure why the Seal Docents started; NPR says that there has never been evidence of any seals being hurt by people, and they're definitely super far from being an endangered species - I read that marine biologists call them Sea Pigeons. :)
In the end, the Seal Docents won and the entire area is roped off from people for part of the year (including right now). BUT, proving that the seals don't mind taking selfies with visitors, the beach on the other side of the lifeguard station is not roped off from people, and tons of seals still flop up onto that people-filled beach and happily pose for pictures! They're soooo cute! We watched them for hours!

There are a couple of things you need to be aware o if you are going to walk out on the curved walkway that surrounds the children's pool.

First, the walkway is very corroded, eroded, and uneven in many places. We had no trouble walking it, but any one with mobility issues or unsteady on their feet will find it very difficult to walk on.

Second, the walkway often has people standing against the rails looking at the seals and sea lions on the beach and in the water. It can be crowded and you need to pay attention as you walk on it.

Third, the seals and sea lions can smell very bad. When we got down there, the stink was pretty bad!

And finally, at high tide, the water crashes against the walkway and pours over it. We saw people near the end get soaked from the crashing waves.

It is fun to see the seals and sea lions, but be careful if you walk out onto the walkway.
